2.1. Collect Data

  • Use Python + snscrape to get tweets:

bash
pip install snscrape pandas

python
import snscrape.modules.twitter as sntwitter
import pandas as pd

query = "LeapScholar since:2025-07-20 until:2025-07-30"
tweets = []
for i, tweet in enumerate(sntwitter.TwitterSearchScraper(query).get_items()):
    if i > 100:
        break
    tweets.append([tweet.date, tweet.content, tweet.url])

df = pd.DataFrame(tweets, columns=["Date", "Content", "URL"])

  • Do the same for Reddit using praw (you'll need Reddit API keys).

2.2. Sentiment Analysis

Use VADER or TextBlob:

bash
pip install nltk textblob

python
from textblob import TextBlob

def get_sentiment(text):
    analysis = TextBlob(text)
    polarity = analysis.sentiment.polarity
    return "Positive" if polarity > 0 else "Negative" if polarity < 0 else "Neutral"

df["Sentiment"] = df["Content"].apply(get_sentiment)

✅ Guide to Build It (Step-by-Step)

Step 1: Setup Your Workspace

  1. Create a GitHub repo (e.g., leap-brand-monitor)

    bash
    python -m venv venv

Step 2: Scrape Mentions of “LeapScholar”

Twitter using snscrape:

python
import snscrape.modules.twitter as sntwitter
import pandas as pd

def fetch_tweets(query, limit=100):
    tweets = []
    for i, tweet in enumerate(sntwitter.TwitterSearchScraper(query).get_items()):
        if i > limit:
            break
        tweets.append([tweet.date, tweet.user.username, tweet.content, tweet.url])
    return pd.DataFrame(tweets, columns=["Date", "User", "Content", "URL"])

query = "LeapScholar since:2025-07-25 until:2025-07-30"
df_tweets = fetch_tweets(query)

Reddit using praw or Google News via newspaper3k (optional if short on time)

Step 3: Add Sentiment Analysis

python
from textblob import TextBlob

def get_sentiment(text):
    polarity = TextBlob(text).sentiment.polarity
    return "Positive" if polarity > 0 else "Negative" if polarity < 0 else "Neutral"

df_tweets["Sentiment"] = df_tweets["Content"].apply(get_sentiment)

Step 4: Build the Streamlit Dashboard

python
import streamlit as st
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

st.title("LeapBrandWatch – Brand Sentiment Monitor")
st.subheader("Mentions of LeapScholar from Twitter")

st.dataframe(df_tweets[["Date", "User", "Content", "Sentiment", "URL"]])

# Sentiment Pie Chart
sentiment_counts = df_tweets["Sentiment"].value_counts()
fig, ax = plt.subplots()
ax.pie(sentiment_counts, labels=sentiment_counts.index, autopct="%1.1f%%")
st.pyplot(fig)

# WordCloud
from wordcloud import WordCloud

text = " ".join(df_tweets["Content"])
wordcloud = WordCloud(width=800, height=400, background_color='white').generate(text)
st.image(wordcloud.to_array())

📄 LeapBrandWatch: A Real-Time Brand Perception Monitor for LeapScholar

Submitted by: Tiru Ram Narla
Role Applied: Product Intern, LeapScholar

🎯 Problem Statement

The Head of Marketing at LeapScholar is responsible for tracking the brand’s online reputation but has limited time. She needs a way to:

  • Monitor public sentiment in real-time,

  • Identify trending or critical conversations,

  • Avoid manually searching through platforms like Twitter, Reddit, or news sites.

💡 Solution Overview: LeapBrandWatch

LeapBrandWatch is a lightweight, real-time dashboard that collects, analyzes, and visualizes public mentions of LeapScholar across social media. It simplifies strategic decision-making by giving the Marketing Head immediate access to:

  • The overall public sentiment,

  • Trending keywords and hashtags,

  • High-impact posts (positive and negative),

  • Platform-wise breakdown of brand buzz.

🛠️ Tools & Technologies Used

ComponentTools Used
Data Collectionsnscrape for Twitter scraping
Sentiment AnalysisTextBlob NLP
DashboardStreamlit
Visualizationmatplotlib, wordcloud
Data Handlingpandas

🔍 Features Implemented

✅ 1. Mention Scraper (Twitter)

  • Captures recent mentions of “LeapScholar” on Twitter.

  • Extracts timestamp, content, author, and URL.

✅ 2. Sentiment Analyzer

  • Each tweet is processed using TextBlob to categorize as:

    • Positive

    • Negative

    • Neutral

✅ 3. Streamlit Dashboard

  • Sentiment Pie Chart – Visualizes the overall emotional tone.

  • Top Mentions Table – Sortable, filterable content with direct links.

  • Word Cloud – Shows frequent keywords associated with LeapScholar.

  • Emerging Trends (Optional) – Keyword frequency across time periods.

📊 Why This Format?

The chosen dashboard format is ideal because:

  • It saves time: All insights are presented in a single-screen interface.

  • It’s dynamic: Refreshes can be configured daily for live updates.

  • It’s actionable: The Head of Marketing can click directly into posts that require attention.

  • It’s flexible: Easily expandable to other platforms (Reddit, YouTube, Google News) or to trigger alerts for spikes in negative sentiment.

This design reduces noise and maximizes clarity, perfectly suiting an executive who needs quick, strategic inputs without the clutter.

🚀 Potential Improvements

  • Include Reddit and Google News scraping

  • Set up email summaries or Slack alerts for daily sentiment spikes

✅ Conclusion

LeapBrandWatch empowers LeapScholar’s Marketing team with a simple but powerful tool to understand and react to public sentiment in real-time. It’s fast, scalable, and focused—just like the decisions it supports.

➤ Step 2: Open it in VS Code

  • Right-click on the folder → Click “Open with Code”

  • In VS Code, click New File and create the following files:

File NamePurpose

requirements.txtList of all Python packages needed

📝 FILE CONTENTS

🔹 app.py (Main file)

Paste this code:

python
import streamlit as st
import snscrape.modules.twitter as sntwitter
import pandas as pd
from textblob import TextBlob
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
from wordcloud import WordCloud

st.set_page_config(layout="wide")
st.title("LeapBrandWatch – Monitor LeapScholar's Online Brand Perception")

# Scrape Tweets
def fetch_tweets(query, limit=100):
    tweets = []
    for i, tweet in enumerate(sntwitter.TwitterSearchScraper(query).get_items()):
        if i >= limit:
            break
        tweets.append([tweet.date, tweet.user.username, tweet.content, tweet.url])
    return pd.DataFrame(tweets, columns=["Date", "User", "Content", "URL"])

df = fetch_tweets("LeapScholar since:2025-07-20 until:2025-07-30", limit=100)

# Sentiment Analysis
def get_sentiment(text):
    polarity = TextBlob(text).sentiment.polarity
    if polarity > 0:
        return "Positive"
    elif polarity < 0:
        return "Negative"
    else:
        return "Neutral"

df["Sentiment"] = df["Content"].apply(get_sentiment)

# Display Data
st.subheader("Recent Mentions of LeapScholar")
st.dataframe(df)

# Sentiment Distribution
st.subheader("Sentiment Distribution")
sentiment_counts = df["Sentiment"].value_counts()
fig, ax = plt.subplots()
ax.pie(sentiment_counts, labels=sentiment_counts.index, autopct="%1.1f%%", startangle=90)
st.pyplot(fig)

# Word Cloud
st.subheader("Trending Keywords")
text = " ".join(df["Content"])
wordcloud = WordCloud(width=800, height=400, background_color='white').generate(text)
st.image(wordcloud.to_array(), use_column_width=True)

Paste this:

nginx

# 📊 LeapBrandWatch – Brand Perception Monitor

LeapBrandWatch is a sentiment and keyword-based brand monitoring dashboard that helps track how the "LeapScholar" brand is perceived across online platforms. This project was created as part of an assignment for the Product Intern role at LeapScholar.

---

## 🚀 Overview

LeapBrandWatch enables a product or marketing manager to:

- Monitor brand sentiment (positive, neutral, negative)
- Extract key entities and hashtags from social posts
- View real-time social media mentions (mocked dataset for demo)
- Gain strategic insights from textual brand mentions

Built using **Python**, **Streamlit**, **TextBlob**, and **Pandas**.

---

## 🔍 Features

- 📈 Sentiment analysis using NLP (TextBlob)
- 🧠 Entity and hashtag extraction
- 📊 Visual dashboards and summary cards
- 🖥️ Streamlit-powered web interface
- ✅ Ready to deploy on Streamlit Community Cloud

---

## 🛠️ Technologies Used

- `Python 3.10+`
- `Streamlit`
- `TextBlob`
- `Pandas`
- `Matplotlib / Seaborn`

ChatGPT said:

The error you're seeing:

csharp
snscrape.base.ScraperException: 4 requests to https://twitter.com/search?...

means that snscrape is failing to fetch data from Twitter. This usually happens due to one of the following:

❌ Common Causes:

  1. Twitter blocking anonymous scraping:

    • snscrape uses guest tokens (no login required), but Twitter now frequently blocks or throttles such requests.

  2. Temporary rate-limiting / bans:

    • Twitter may rate-limit or block your IP address temporarily for sending too many automated requests.

  3. Network issues or firewalls:

    • If you're on a restricted network (e.g. school, office), outbound traffic to Twitter might be blocked.

✅ Solutions:

✅ Option 1: Try different keywords or reduce the time range

Use a smaller date window or just the keyword (e.g. "LeapScholar") without date filters:

python
df = fetch_tweets("LeapScholar", limit=50)

✅ Option 2: Add a delay in your fetch function

To avoid rate-limiting:

python
import time
def fetch_tweets(query, limit=100):
    tweets = []
    for i, tweet in enumerate(sntwitter.TwitterSearchScraper(query).get_items()):
        if i >= limit:
            break
        tweets.append([tweet.date, tweet.user.username, tweet.content])
        time.sleep(1)  # sleep 1 second per request
    return pd.DataFrame(tweets, columns=["Date", "User", "Tweet"])

✅ Option 3: Use cached or sample data instead

To bypass the scraping issue entirely, use sample tweets saved in CSV (I can generate that for you if needed).

✅ Option 4: Use Twitter API (paid / requires authentication)

snscrape is unofficial and vulnerable to breaking changes. A more stable way is to use the Twitter API — but this requires a developer account and access tokens.

You can:

  • Try Option 1 or 2 above

  • Or tell me: Do you want sample tweet data I generate and you load from a CSV instead?

That way you can complete the Streamlit dashboard and assignment without relying on live scraping.

✏️ STEP 2: Modify app.py to Load the CSV Instead of Scraping

Open app.py and replace your fetch_tweets() function with this:

python
import pandas as pd

def fetch_tweets_from_csv(file_path):
    df = pd.read_csv(file_path)
    df['Date'] = pd.to_datetime(df['Date'])
    return df

Then, in your main function, use this line instead of calling sntwitter:

python
df = fetch_tweets_from_csv("leapscholar_sample_tweets.csv")

This tells your Streamlit app to load tweet data from the CSV file instead of trying to scrape from Twitter.
